Pros: Relatively low time complexity and high computing efficiency in general
Cons:
Not suitable for non-convex data, relatively sensitive to the outliers,
easily drawn into local optimal, the number of clusters needed to be preset, and the clustering result sensitive to the number of clusters

Pros:
Suitable for the data set with arbitrary shape and attribute of arbitrary type, the hierarchical relationship among clusters easily detected, and relatively
high scalability in general
Cons:
Relatively high in time complexity in general, the number of clusters
needed to be preset.
Evaluation criteria:
Adjusted Rand, Jaccard, Normalized mutual information and
Fowlkes Mallows
https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0210236

Pros: More realistic to give the probability of belonging, relatively high accuracy of clustering
Cons:
Relatively low scalability in general, easily drawn into local optimal,
the clustering result sensitive to the initial parameter values, and the number of clusters needed to be preset.
Evaluation criteria:
Normalized Mutual
Information,  Omega-Index, Supervised Fuzzy Evaluation Criterion (SFEC), Unsupervised Fuzzy Evaluation Criterion (UFEC)
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.asoc.2016.12.019

Pros:
More realistic to give the probability of belonging, relatively high
scalability by changing the distribution, number of clusters and so on, and supported
by the well developed statistical science
Cons:
The premise not completely correct, involved in many parameters
which have a strong influence on the clustering result and relatively high time complexity.
Evaluation criteria:
Rand Index, F index,
Jaccard index, Fowlkes-Mallows index
https://d1wqtxts1xzle7.cloudfront.net/74347295

Pros: Clustering in high efficiency and suitable for data with arbitrary shape
Cons:
Clustering result with low quality when the density
of data space isn’t even, a memory with big size needed when the data volume is big, and the clustering result highly sensitive to the parameters
Evaluation criteria:
Adjusted Rand, Jaccard, Normalized mutual information and
Fowlkes Mallows
https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0210236

Pros: Clustering in high efficiency, the clustering result with high accuracy
Cons:
The time complexity increases dramatically with the increase
of graph complexity
Evaluation criteria:
F-measure, 
Jaccard coefficient, 
entropy, mutual information
https://aclanthology.org/W10-2301.pdf

Pros:
Low time complexity, high scalability and suitable for parallel
processing and increment updating
Cons:
The clustering result is sensitive to the granularity (the mesh size),
the high calculation efficiency at the cost of reducing the quality of clusters and reducing the clustering accuracy
Evaluation criteria:
Davies–Bouldin indicator,
Dunn indicator, Silhouette coefficient,
Confusion matrix, Mutual information,
Fowlkes–Mallows indicator, Jaccard indicator,
F indicator, Rand indicator
https://doi.org/10.1007/s40745-015-0040-1

Pros:
Clustering in high efficiency,
high scalability, 
dealing with outliers, effectively and suitable for data with arbitrary shape and high dimension
Cons:
The premise not completely correct, the clustering result sensitive
to the parameters.
Evaluation criteria:
Davies–Bouldin indicator,
Dunn indicator, Silhouette coefficient,
Confusion matrix, Mutual information,
Fowlkes–Mallows indicator, Jaccard indicator,
F indicator, Rand indicator
https://doi.org/10.1007/s40745-015-0040-1

Pros:
Diverse and well developed models providing means to describe data adequately and each model having its own special characters that may 
bring about some significant 
advantages in some specific areas
Cons:
Relatively high time complexity in general, the premise not completely
correct, and the clustering result sensitive to the parameters of selected
models.
Evaluation criteria:
Davies–Bouldin indicator,
Dunn indicator, Silhouette coefficient,
Confusion matrix, Mutual information,
Fowlkes–Mallows indicator, Jaccard indicator,
F indicator, Rand indicator
https://doi.org/10.1007/s40745-015-0040-1

Pros:
More easy to cluster in the high dimensional feature space, suitable for data with arbitrary shape, able to analyze the noise and separate the overlapping clusters, and not needed to have the preliminary knowledge about the topology
of data
Cons:
The clustering result sensitive to the type of kernel and its parameters,
time complexity being high, and not suitable for large-scale data.
Evaluation criteria:
Cluster Validity 
index based on 
Density-involved Distance(CVDD)
https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-030-73819-8_19#Sec12

Pros: Robust, scalable, able to be parallel and taking advantage of the strengths of the involved algorithms
Cons:
Inadequate understanding about the difference among the initial
clustering results, existing deficiencies of the design of the consensus function
Evaluation criteria:
NMI-based cluster evaluator, the MAX-based cluster evaluator and the APMM-based cluster evaluator
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10462-018-9642-2

Pros: Algorithm with the character of overcoming being easily drawn into local optimal and getting the global optimal, easy to understand the algorithm
Cons:
Low scalability, low operating efficiency and not suitable for high
dimensional or large-scale data
Evaluation criteria:
Silhouette statistic index,
Dunn index, Caliński–Harabasz 
index, the CS index, the 
Davies–Bouldin index
https://doi.org/10.1109/TSMCB.2012.2188509

Pros:
The number of parameters
involved in this kind of 
algorithm being small, 
the determination of the 
center of a cluster based 
on the potential information of sample data
Cons:
The clustering result sensitive to the parameters of the algorithm,
the algorithm model not able to describe the change law of data completely
Evaluation criteria:
Jaccard Measure and the Efficiency of clusters
https://www.academia.edu/download/54340950/IRJET-V3I11272.pdf

Pros:
Suitable for the data set with arbitrary shape and high dimension,
converged to the global optimal, only the similarity matrix needed as the input,
and not sensitive to the outliers
Cons:
The clustering result sensitive to the scaling parameter, time complexity
relatively high, unclear about the construction of similarity matrix, the
selection of eigenvector not optimized and the number of clusters needed to be
preset
Evaluation criteria:
Adjusted Rand, Jaccard, Normalized mutual information and
Fowlkes Mallows
https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0210236

Pros:
Simple and clear algorithm idea, insensitive to the outliers and the
number of clusters not needed to be preset
Cons:
High time complexity, not suitable for very large data set, and the
clustering result sensitive to the parameters involved in AP algorithm
Evaluation criteria:
Sum of similarities, clustering accuracy, normalized mutual information
https://doi.org/10.1109/ACCESS.2020.3012740

Pros:
Simple and clear algorithm idea, suitable for the data set with arbitrary
shape and insensitive to the outliers
Cons:
Relatively high time complexity, relatively strong subjectivity for
the selection of the cluster center based on the decision graph and the clustering
result sensitive to the parameters involved in DD algorithm

Evaluation criteria:
Compactness index (CPI), separation index (SPI), Davies–Bouldin index (DBI) and the connectivity index (CNI)
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.future.2020.06.053

External criterion which measures
the degree of correspondence between the clusters obtained from our clustering algorithms
and the classes assigned a priori
https://doi.org/10.1023/A:1009769707641
